This table lists all these comets, including the date of their perihelion passage and the expected maximum brightness in 2014 (estimated total magnitude)., 336=All the comets which are expected to become brighter than magnitude 16 during 2014 have been added to TheSkyLive.com, so it’s now possible to track them, compute ephemerides and visualize their predicted light curve. textBeforeTable: Comets passing perihelion in 2014 All the comets which are expected to become brighter than magnitude 16 during 2014 have been added to TheSkyLive.com, so it’s now possible to track them, compute ephemerides and visualize their predicted light curve. Those comets are linked directly in the table below. During 2014 there will be 73 comets  passing their perihelion (data from JPL Horizons). This table lists all these comets, including the date of their perihelion passage and the expected maximum brightness in 2014 (estimated total magnitude). textAfterTable: As usual, when reading this data it is important to keep in mind that the predicted brightness might not be accurate. In fact comets are highly dynamic bodies which might become extremely bright because of sudden, unforeseen, outbursts, or faint because of lack of nuclear activity. According to current data, comet C/2013 V5 (Oukaimeden), is the most promising one, and should become quite bright in late september 2014, when it will pass perihelion at about 0.6 AU from the sun. Comet 169P/NEAT will pass perihelion on Feb 12 2014, and visibility conditions should improve during beginning of March, in particular in the Northern emisphere, where it will be visible in the evenings, and will set a couple of hours after the sun. January 4, 2014 in astronomy, comets. Tags: 2014, comets, comets in 2014 Related posts C/2015 O1, an interesting and promising new comet
